Award.AwardTitle: Diffusion Processes and Partial Differential Equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on some of the central topics in the modern theory of partial differential equations (PDE) and diffusion processes. The problems arise from practical applications and, in mathematical terms, are described as optimal control of random processes, optimal filtering of diffusion processes, and white-noise-driven stochastic PDE (SPDE). The problems are formulated in the language of the theory of fully nonlinear PDE, and the project includes investigation of numerical methods for finding their solutions.

Fully nonlinear partial differential equations arise in a multitude of contexts, including control theory, optimal mass transportation problems, and geometry, to name just three. Rigidity and other characteristics of all kinds of hulls (of, say, ships or missiles) are described in terms of such equations. Control problems and fully nonlinear equations also turn up in engineering, target tracking, pattern recognition, and a host of other applied areas. There are many random processes that it is both desirable and important to control (e.g., the performance of a stock portfolio, the trajectory of a missile). In target tracking, for instance, it is important to emphasize that the trajectory of a projectile is observed, in general, with certain errors or noises. Therefore, the first problem in controlling the trajectory is to filter the noise out of the observations. Such problems were initially solved by Kalman and Bucy, who constructed and used their filter during the Apollo program. Needless to say, much more work needs to be done in order to achieve more accurate results. Improved filters would be relevant to endeavors such as weather forecasting (or, more generally, climate change forecasting), which is one of the possible concrete applications of stochastic partial differential equations and the theory of filtering and prediction of random processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project relates to a few very important modern topics in the theories of Diffusion Processes and Partial Differential Equations, arising from practical applications and in mathematical terms described as optimal control of random processes, optimal filtering of diffusion processes, white noise driven stochastic partial differential equations arising in populational genetics, the theory of fully nonlinear equations, including investigation of the methods of finding their solutions.

 
The most famous fully nonlinear elliptic equation is the Monge-Ampere equation which arises, for instance, in the optimal mass transportation problem and in geometry. Rigidity and other characteristics of all kinds of hulls are described in terms of such equations. Control problems and fully nonlinear partial differential equations also arise in engineering, target tracking, pattern recognition, and many other areas.

If you want to transport a given mass at location A to another location B in a certain optimal way, a Monge-Ampere-like equation appears. This equation generally does not admit a formula for solutions and we can only approximate the solutions numerically. The problem how to do this and how good the approximations are is one of the problems I study in my grant.

There are many random processes which we want to control, for instance, the performance of a portfolio or the trajectory of a missile. It turns out that very large class of control problems can be written in terms of problems for fully nonlinear elliptic and parabolic second order equations, which are called Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equations.

Coming back to controlling the trajectory of a missile, it is important to emphasize that the trajectory itself is observed in general with certain errors or noises, so that we have a so-called Hidden Markov Model. Therefore the first problem is to filter the noise out of the observations. First such problems were solved by Kalman and Bucy, who constructed and used their filter during the Apollo program. This filtering problem leads to so-called stochastic partial differential equations (SPDEs), which were also used, for instance, to describe free fields in relativistic quantum mechanics, hydromagnetic dynamo-process in cosmology, diffraction in random-heterogeneous media in statistical physics, dynamics of populations for models with geographical structure in population genetics, etc. Solving the corresponding equations on computers requires knowing how "good" the solutions are. Here comes the need of Hormander-like theory.
 
Weather forecast is one of possible practical applications of the theory of filtering and prediction of random processes.

In the past probabilistic models as well as those based on differential equations (deterministic or stochastic) have shown themselves effective in very many practical problems ranging from the ones in biology to satellite launching.  There is no need to explain that much more work should be done to get satisfactory results, say in weather forecasting.
